intro: Andryala ragusina subsp. macrocephala, commonly known as the Sicilian bellflower, is a rare and endemic plant species native to southern Italy. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils in mountainous regions. It has narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, clustered flowers during the summer months. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
